title: 108_s501
content: The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" establishes a grant program for gifted and talented students under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This program includes authorized activities for supporting these students. The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" recognizes the need to provide specialized services for gifted students from diverse backgrounds, including those with disabilities or English as a second language. Elementary school gifted students often surpass a significant portion of yearly material in various subjects. Elementary and secondary school teachers lack training to meet the needs of gifted and talented students, who have already mastered a significant portion of the material before the school year begins. Most teachers lack training to support gifted students, who often rely on public schools for education. Parents play a crucial role in advocating for appropriate services for their gifted children. Parents and families are crucial partners in developing educational services for gifted students, requiring access to information and support. There is no federal mandate to serve the 3 million gifted students in the nation, leading to varying resources and support at the state and local levels. Some states and local educational agencies provide resources for gifted students, but others do not, leading to disparities in services. It is crucial for highly capable students to receive an education that prepares them for innovative work to secure the nation's position. The performance of twelfth-grade advanced students in the US on international assessments was among the lowest globally. The performance of twelfth-grade advanced students in the US on international assessments was among the lowest globally. In 1990, very little funding was allocated for challenging programs for gifted students in the US. The program aims to provide challenging programming for the Nation's gifted and talented students through competitive and formula grants to State educational agencies for developing or expanding gifted and talented education programs. The Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies to enable them to provide direct educational services and materials to gifted and talented students. Grant funds can be used for various authorized activities, including developing or expanding gifted and talented education programs. Grant funds provided under this chapter can be used for activities such as providing direct educational services to gifted and talented students, including curriculum compacting, modified curriculum, acceleration, independent study, and dual enrollment. However, funds cannot be used for purchasing or upgrading technological hardware. The grant funds provided under this chapter can be used for educational services for gifted students, but not for purchasing or upgrading technological hardware. State educational agencies receiving the grant can use up to 10% for dissemination of program information, technical assistance, monitoring, parental education support, and State gifted education. The grant funds under this chapter can be used for educational services for gifted students, parental education support, and creating a State gifted education advisory board. State educational agencies can use up to 50% of the funds for administrative costs. "SEC. 5467A. ALLOTMENTS TO STATES." The Secretary reserves funds for programs in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The remaining amount is allotted to states based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17. No state can receive less than half of one percent. The Secretary allocates funds for programs in Bureau of Indian Affairs schools and states based on populations aged 5-17. States must receive a minimum of 0.5% of the total amount allotted. If a state does not apply for funding, the Secretary reallocates the amount to other states. "State application for funding is required, with a minimum allocation of 0.5% of total funds allotted." To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary containing assurances on how the funds will be used to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, make grants to local educational agencies, and follow the guidelines of the chapter. The State educational agency must use funds to make competitive grants to local educational agencies, ensuring funds supplement, not supplant, state and local funds for gifted students. The agency must provide matching funds of at least 10% of the grant amount and develop program assessment models for accountability and effectiveness. The State educational agency must provide matching funds for grants and develop program assessment models for accountability and effectiveness. The Secretary will approve state applications that meet the requirements of this section. The State educational agency must allocate at least 90 percent of funds to local educational agencies through a competitive process for grants to carry out authorized activities. Grants should be sufficient to meet the needs of students. Local educational agencies must submit applications for funding. To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a local educational agency must submit an application to the State educational agency. The application must include assurances on how funds will be used to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, a plan to meet their educational needs, and a commitment to training personnel in this area. The local educational agency must assure that funds will supplement, not replace, the amount spent on education and services for gifted and talented students. The State educational agency must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the number of students served and activities supported with funds under the Gifted and Talented Students Education Act. Recipients of funds can serve gifted students alongside those with similar needs, and private school children and teachers can participate. In grants under this chapter, the Secretary ensures equitable participation of students and teachers in private nonprofit schools, including professional development programs. The term 'gifted and talented' is defined under applicable State law or by the State educational agency if no State law exists. The term 'State' refers to each of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. If a State does not have a law defining a term, it will be defined according to section 9101. Authorization of Appropriations for the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program is set at $170,000,000 annually from 2004 to 2010. $7,500,000 is allocated for Chapter A, with the remainder for Chapter 2. In the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program, changes are made to various sections including renaming "this part" to "this chapter" and redesignating subsections.
